thoughts: It was a pleasure to have been hosted by you and Ariana on a tour of your property. Don and I appreciate your enthusiasm to learn more about your land. As you are both affiliated with the Columbia Land Conservancy, you are well informed, and I hope that my feedback will be useful.   One of the drawbacks of our visit was that spring hadnâ€™t quite arrived at your altitude â€“ your land was still in its winter hibernation with autumn leaves as ground cover and an abundance of dead twigs and branches all over. We were unable to actually see what growth the land nurtured, other than the obvious â€“ the trees.  While I'd like to focus mainly on your wooded acres rather than in the immediate vicinity of your house, I saw that there is a pond next to your house that collects water from the hillsides. This water overflows into a stream and moves into a pond lower down on the hill (not on your property), and continues to another stream, whose destination I was unable to discern. The only comment I will make about that pond and subsequent watercourse is that once you can identify what shrubs you have growing around your pond, you may want to check for invasive species there as well. If you stock your pond, your fish may also go downhill to the lower pond and you will lose stock.  The largely wooded area of 23 acres: the extensive woods east of your house Our observations: You have a property that is pretty clear from the usual invasive plants that we see in Northeastern Columbia County. The invasives common up here in the northeastern part of the county are the Japanese stilt grass, autumn olive, multiflora rose and oriental bittersweet. Most of the time these seeds travel on tires and peoplesâ€™ shoes. Although I didnâ€™t see these common invasives, we noticed that there were several clumps of barberry, it was hard to tell if they were common or Japanese invasive barberry. The Japanese form has reddish leaves and red fruit and spreads throughout the forest by seed dispersal.     Japanese barberry Photo by Kathy Smith, Ohio State University Extension. The common form has greenish sharply toothed simple leaves, the flowers are pale yellow. Removal suggestions are provided by Penn State extension. https://extension.psu.edu/japanese-barberry#:~:text=It%20has%20relatively%20shallow%20roots,areas%20of%20special%20ecological%20sensitivity.  Research conducted by the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station, an independent state agency, reported higher populations of deer ticks in areas where Japanese barberry was present than in areas where barberry was managed (Williams et. al. 2017). It is hypothesized that the dense growth of barberry creates microhabitat beneficial to tick survival. It is important that you protect yourself against ticks while you tackle barberry. https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/reviews/sawyer-permethrin-premium-insect-repellent-review/  The forested land covers the area of the former logging acreage with roads both built for logging and for traversing to other potential sites for building houses. You informed us that the lady who had owned all this acreage sold some of the land to Mass Fish and Wildlife and some of the land to you. Your land abuts that of the Fish and Wildlife preserve. It appears that the previous logging operators harvested trees in such a way that the remaining trees were well spread out with ample sunshine available for each tree. There were no dense thickets of trees and you do not have stands of one particular species.   What was surprising was that there isnâ€™t much of a middle story in the forest but there is an understory of rather small trees. There were also very few evergreens, we found some small spruce trees, and the larger stand of evergreens was up on a hill some distance away. Among the remaining trees were a few oaks (red, white), maples, some ash (viable now, because of the leaves present on the ground), black cherry, an elm, and an abundance of (betula) birches (paper, silver, yellow, etc). Unlike the Pittsfield state forest which is not far from your land, you do not have cedar and eastern pine trees. While it is possible that all the cedar has been harvested, that would be unexpected inasmuch as loggers tend to leave some valuable timber behind for future harvests. The species of timber that are valued in the marketplace from the Northeast include red oak, sugar maple, yellow birch, white ash, red maple, and white birch; softwoods include white pine and red spruce.    One detriment of a logged forest is the arrival of growth that is not beneficial to the forest. These trees, European beeches, have set up in empty land spaces and look like relatively young trees. They have a very smooth light gray bark and tend to develop in groups and spread and outcompete native trees. These trees should be culled as they will shade out your fragile understory and take up valuable real estate. They can either be cut down and the outer cambium layer treated with an herbicide or left to stand but treated to kill the entire organism by a method called â€˜hack and squirtâ€™. For more on this process go to https://extension.psu.edu/what-is-a-hack-and-squirt-treatment. This website also covers cut stump herbicide treatment.   There were regions on your property where the land was wet, more so than in other spots and not just from the recent rains. It may be in this area, once spring has progressed,you might see ferns as you indicated. Usually, ferns appear on logging roads where the land has been disturbed. They tend to grow in moist soil. Ferns are hard to remove, but you said that you might like to have some ferns around but be aware that they can spread.   This is the information that we gleaned from the intake form To enjoy beauty/scenery 	Extremely Important To protect nature or biological diversity 	Extremely Important For privacy 	Slightly Important For land investment 	Not at all Important  To pass land on to my children or other heirs 	Moderately important For timber products, e.g. logs or pulpwood 	Slightly important For hunting 	Slightly important For recreation, other than hunting 	Extremely Important   In addition, you remarked that you might want to forage, grow mushrooms, and ginseng. In fact, you said that you had started a stand of ginseng plants.  Forest Age and Maturity: Shane and I reviewed your intake form to address any specifics you might want covered. Our assumption was that for many years your land was part of a larger parcel of forested land and had not been used for crop production probably due to the presence of wet areas/wetlands. Our guess that it was probably used for timber production under section 480-a of the Real Property Tax Law when it was part of a larger piece of land.  Our main concern is that throughout the property, there is little understory regeneration of trees. It is what folks at Cornell describe as an "even-aged" forest. The trees are maybe 50-60 years old and in some cases may be older. There appeared to be a stone wall which suggests that there may have been a farm for crops or livestock many years ago. However, based on the lack of quick growing trees or invasives this may not be an accurate conclusion. This can be nailed down with some searching of the Agricultural Census schedule data that farmers were required to complete in mid-19th century. If you are curious just ask. More reading material: https://smallfarms.cornell.edu/2022/10/anticipating-the-next-forest-ecology-and-management-for-sustaining-forests/   Stewardship Plan:  It may be helpful to plan out proposed landscape level changes by breaking them out into a series of smaller projects. For ease of tractor access, I would probably start on the logging road.   The area populated with ferns may be an ideal spot to plant some trees. You can use the USDA soil survey map to determine which trees will do well. Your property's Soil Map from the USDA-NRCS can be found at the following site: https://websoilsurvey.sc.egov.usda.gov/app/WebSoilSurvey.aspx. You can get an idea about the type of soil in your particular area, if you decide to add trees. Planting a tree in fern populated areas would require clearing the ground of ferns and digging a large enough hole to put in a young tree.   In addition, you can also plant hardwoods (some are already present on your property) in areas where there is a lack of trees. The aim is to have trees of varying ages and/or heights so you have a ground story with grasses, (if the sunlight reaches it), a middle story with younger trees and an upper story with mature trees. Black Walnut: Should you ever decide to embark on adding trees, this species could be good for the lower land where the ferns are plentiful because (1) it is nut-bearing, thus positive for wildlife; (2) it grows well in rich alluvial soils; (3) it is allelopathic, keeps invasives at bay (via its juglone chemical), but do not put your vegetable garden near it; (4) it makes beautiful flooring, should you want to take one of them down for Black Walnut flooring for your daughter's house in 30 years. Silver Maple: Can be planted in a swampish area and is a fast grower. Sycamore: Another fast grower and does not mind wet feet.   Apart from the hardwoods on your property you have black cherry trees. These trees do not mind wet feet either and are monetarily valuable to grow. They would make great furniture/cabinet material if you ever decided to harvest them. Be aware that these trees may suffer from Gummosis -- Black Cherry trees ooze a dark gelatinous substance from their bark, which often happens when they are stressed, for example when there is an extremely dry spell. Alternatively, that ooze could be a fungus growing on your black cherry tree.  This fungus is called Apiosporina morbosa. More information is available about the fungus and its management at:,https://chemung.cce.cornell.edu/resources/black-knot-disease-of-cherry-and-plum. The fungus is likely to spread but not the gummosis.   All the above listed trees need full sunlight and should grow well if there is no competition, and they might reduce the harm being done by ferns. As you get more familiar with trees, you can add burr oaks which could prosper in wettish areas. Mushroom cultivation: You expressed a wish to grow mushrooms and ginseng on your property, and said that you have some mushroom cultivation experience. The Cornell Cooperative Extension of Columbia/Greene County has classes offered periodically throughout the year. As you probably know, you need a water source and shade, which you have in the area near the stream, for growing shitake. A source of hardwood logs too is required and you should keep that in mind when trees have fallen due to wind damage. You can find the courses offered on the right-hand side of the web page. https://ccecolumbiagreene.org/. If you get on their email list, they will send you monthly reminders. In case you are interested in cutting the wood yourselves, there are chainsaw classes held by Tracey Testo-Smith specifically designed for women taught at the Cornell Cooperative Extension.   Forage Management: You expressed an interest in this after we found a single ramp plant on our walk. We occasionally have foraging walks in various areas of Greene County. Also, there is a class given by Cornell that you can enroll in to learn more about this activity. https://cals.cornell.edu/education/degrees-programs/forage-management   Invasive parasites and other dead trees:  Emerald Ash Borer... Impossible to mitigate at this stage. If you have viable ash trees they tend to die off in this area from the emerald ash borer incursion. Ash can be used for firewood or standing snag as shelter for animals. It is sometimes useful to keep standing dead trees, they are a haven for birds and small mammals and insects and provide a food source.  You might see oaks denuded of leaves from the spongy moth. These moths usually do not continue to harm trees for more than 3 years. The old sticky tape around the trunk is a useful way to trap caterpillars that hatch in early spring.  Ferns: If you wish to control ferns, here is a good resource. yohttps://extension.psu.edu/controlling-understory-fern-competition-for-regeneration-success  If you wish to add valuable hardwood to your forest or add native shrubs and trees, the DEC has Regenerate NY Forestry Cost Share Program. You pay 20% of the total bill. You will need to hire/designate a forester and have a plan. Minimum grant from NYS is $10,000 which means your minimum cost under the program is $2,500 on a bill of $12,500. This is granted on a first come, first serve process and stops when the money runs out. Project can take 3 years; so you can amortize your outlay. They have an approved list of contractors to do the work. https://www.dec.ny.gov/lands/119950.html. You can, by this means, add more trees to your woods where there are big gaps or where you have lost trees to storm damage. Remember that because of climate change the keystone species in our areas are changing. For example, sugar maples may not survive In our area in the long term because of warmer temperatures and more rains. Be aware of the changes and order trees accordingly.  The DEC Saratoga Nursery sells trees every year at great prices, typically starting in January. The good stuff goes quickly, so you need to keep your eye out on their site. Here's is the link for the 2024 sale back in January: https://dec.ny.gov/nature/forests-trees/saratoga-tree-nursery/nursery-stock-availability  Sales of trees take place each year, in the counties...by the County Soil and Water Conservation Districts, at discounted prices. Specifically, Albany, Columbia and Greene counties recently. The Soil and water conservation is administered by people who are also members of the Cornell Cooperative extension. Soil and Water Conservation District | Albany County, NY  If you choose to become a MFO, you might be interested in the conference of NY Forest Owners Association & Northern Woodlands entitled â€œEnhancing the Values of Family Forests in the Northeastâ€. The details are available at: Cornell Cooperative Extension | NYFOA-NW Conference (cceschuyler.org)  Space is limited to the first one hundred people to register on a first-come basis, so please register by May 8th at: https://reg.cce.cornell.edu/Woodland_Conference_244. Rooms at the historic Seneca Lodge (www.senecalodge.com) can be reserved for about $115/night by calling 607-535-2014 during weekday business hours.  For other lodging options and things to do while in the world-famous Watkins Glen Area, visit: https://www.explorewatkinsglen.com  We loved your tour, your enthusiasm, and your property. We wish you the very best in healthy stewardship of your property. If I have forgotten anything, please feel free to reach out. Always feel free to further write to any of us singly or together if you have questions.

Beech was present but not in excessive abundance. We spoke about the management of Beech. Daniel is thinking about Game of Logging and thinning small poles for firewood, camp wood and mushroom bolts. problems: The property at 215/217 Route 375 is a combination of 3 connected lots. Each lot contains different areas with respect to topography, forest growth, etc. The first thing discussed was the need for a forest management plan, even a rough one to start, to help the owner identify and prioritize issues and solutions in a structured way with respect to each different area.  For example, one lot borders a heavily traveled street (Route 375) and the owner expressed an interest in creating some type of privacy / noise barrier for that area.   There is a wetland area, about an acre square, that is overgrown with some invasives (japanese Stiltgrass, Japanese barberry) as well as a variety of low shrubs and grasses. The owner would like to create an elevated walkway over the area at some point and use the area primarily for wildlife and as a buffer around the main part of her property.   There is a stream running through much of the property, that the owner would like to support and maintain.   We also discussed creating some walking paths, both to use for recreational purposes that she is interested in, and also for the more practical purpose of being able to access areas of her property more easily.  Right now, much is overgrown and somewhat inaccessible.  The owner was initially interested in supporting some type of â€œForaging Cropâ€ to make some money off the property, and we discussed what the challenges and limitations of various types of crops were. She seemed very interested in berry bushes, and we also discussed Shiitake mushrooms and Ginseng.  Because she has a mature Sugar Maple stand sheâ€™s tapped trees in the past for syrup and even has a makeshift â€œsugar shackâ€ set up.   There are a number of mature trees with some diversity, however the stand is mainly Eastern White Pine, Sugar Maple, and some Oaks. There are a number of Spice Bush trees in various stages.  Because there were a lot of trees that had fallen in the not too distant past, there were areas of sunlight were native Eastern White Pine seedlings were growing.  We discussed general tree planting ideas for various areas of the property. Seedlings v. Saplings v. native growth. We discussed the challenges and considerations for each: water, light, and various strategies for limiting damage from deer.   As far as invasives, there was an area with Japanese Barberry in abundance and we discussed dealing with it before it becomes harder to manage. There are areas with Japanese Stiltgrass and Japanese Pachysandra. We discussed how both of those ground covering plants could limit the growth of natives. In areas where the Stiltgrass and Pachsandra had grown there was not much other growth.    In looking at the canopy I noticed some serious leaf damage which lead to identifying Spongy Moth egg sacs on nearby trees. We discussed steps to eradicate the egg sacs and what to look out for next spring.   Iâ€™ll be following up with the owner with an email summarizing the visit and also attaching a few PDF handouts of issues related to our discussion.
action_other: The main management activity that the owner is likely to pursue within 12 months (from question below) should be coming up with a solid management plan.  I mentioned consulting with a forester, but I got the impression she's going to do it herself to start.
thoughts: I gave the owner a copy of the Forest Resource Management Book as well as some other various paper handouts. I'd love to get more copies of the book for future visits.  Thanks!

problems: The class from Ithaca college, consisting of 19 students and 2 instructors, was taken to 3 locations on the property. The second location was the site of the Northeast Timber growing contest, where timber stand improvement was discussed and the students realized that not all trees in a stand should be left to grow, thinning is necessary to produce good timber. An area of 1 acre and 1/100 of an acre was marked out to show the final number of trees that need to be left to grow good timber. The impact of deer on forest regeneration was demonstrated, pointing out that high deer populations greatly hinder good timber production. the third stop was a sawmill demonstration, showing how lumber is made from logs. Also demonstrated was how to properly dry lumber and how the lumber produced on our farm was used to build 2 buildings and to reside an old barn.

thoughts: The owner recently lost her husband and has not been as active in the management of her woodlot as she was when he was alive. She is interested is getting more involved again, and in being a good steward of her land. But, she is just starting to get her arms around the task and to finalize her long- and short-term goals. She has no heirs, so we touched briefly on estate and tax planning options including the 480A program and land conservation easements. She has also had issues with neighbors trespassing and with encroachments, so we talked about the importance of boundary marking, posting, and about timber theft. She is interested in planting some trees, so we discussed the Soil Survey Mapper and the information it can provide in support of that activity (as well as others), and I provided her with some examples of its products. We talked extensively about the value of a management plan, grant possibilities through the NRCS and NYS, and about the types of foresters, including free ones as well as how to find a Consulting Forester. I provided her with an extensive list (in both hard copy and electronic formats) of online references on a variety of subjects. I also provided several paper references in the form of bulletins and pamphlets for her to review at her leisure and recommended a couple of good books on managing a woodlot. One of her primary objectives for the visit was to get some insight into options for her dying Ash and to determine what other invasives she might have other than EAB, Multi-floral Rose, and Honey-suckle and we discussed her options for dealing with all three.  Perhaps most importantly, during our woods walk, I identified the presence of both HWA and BLD, which she did not know were present.

thoughts: The property was fairly homogenously pole/sm sawtimber hemlock stand with beech understory. Stand was heavily harvested (high-graded) for white pine 20 years ago. I suggested that they hire a forester to consider doing a small clearcut/seed tree harvest of the dense hemlock (Finch-Pryun is close and has good pulp prices). The goal would be to create some early successional habitat for diversity and white pine regeneration stand. The property once had lots of mature white pine sawtimber.
